meanings.def: the part of the body on top of the neck containing the eyes, nose, mouth and brain
examples: She nodded her head in agreement.
He shook his head in disbelief.
The boys hung their heads in shame.
She turned her head to look at him.
They bowed their heads in prayer.
She tilted her head back and closed her eyes.
to raise/lift/lower your head
He was shot in the head and died ten minutes later.
The driver suffered head injuries.
He still has a good head of hair (= a lot of hair).
a woman with a beautiful head of chestnut hair
He lay writhing on the ground, clutching his head in pain.
He put his head around the door.
He put his head in his hands, exasperated.
He scratched his head, not understanding a word.
He shaved his head and became a monk.
He threw his head back and laughed out loud.
Her head tilted to one side as she considered the question.
His head drooped and tears fell into his lap.
I banged my head on the door frame.
I'm normally asleep as soon as my head hits the pillow.
She declined with a brief shake of the head.
She jerked her head in the direction of the door.
She rested her head on his shoulder.
She sat with bowed head.
The ambassador dismissed him with a curt nod of the head.
The city gates were adorned with severed heads.
The soldiers were ordered to fire over the heads of the crowd.
The thunder burst with a grand crash above our heads.

meanings.def: the mind or brain
examples: I sometimes wonder what goes on in that head of yours.
I wish you'd use your head (= think carefully before doing or saying something).
The thought never entered my head.
His head was spinning (= he felt dizzy or confused) after only one drink.
in somebody's head I can't work it out in my head—I need a calculator.
She started hearing voices in her head.
into somebody's head Who's been putting such weird ideas into your head (= making you believe that)?
out of somebody's head I can't get that tune out of my head.
Try to put the exams out of your head (= stop thinking about them).
It was the first name that popped into my head.
It was an accident, said a voice inside his head.
I decided to go for a walk to clear my head.
He looked at me as if I needed my head examined.
Don't bother your pretty little head with things like that!
It never entered my head that he might be lying.

meanings.def: the size of a person’s or animal’s head, used as a measurement of distance or height
examples: She's a good head taller than her sister.
The favourite won by a short head (= a distance slightly less than the length of a horse's head).

meanings.def: a continuous pain in your head
examples: I woke up with a really bad head this morning.

meanings.def: the person in charge of a group of people or an organization
examples: head of something the heads of government/state
She resigned as head of department.
I've asked the department head for an appointment.
a former head of the Hong Kong Stock Exchange
He is deputy head of the National Railway Museum.
the crowned heads (= the kings and queens) of Europe
I was head coach of a Little League basketball team in Pittsburgh.
the head gardener/chef/waiter
He is only the nominal head of the company.
The Queen is titular head of the Church of England.
The Bishop is head of the Church in Kenya.

meanings.def: the person in charge of a school or college
examples: I've been called in to see the Head.
the deputy head
I remember sitting outside the Head's office waiting to be called in.
She is deputy head of Greenlands Comprehensive, a struggling inner city school.
The minister has written to every secondary head in Scotland.

meanings.def: the side of a coin that has a picture of the head of a person on it, used as one choice when a coin is tossed to decide something
examples: I called heads and it came down tails.

meanings.def: the end of a long narrow object that is larger or wider than the rest of it
examples: the head of a nail

meanings.def: the top or highest part of something
examples: at the head of the page
They finished the season at the head of their league.

meanings.def: the place where a river begins
the most important seat at a table
examples: The President sat at the head of the table.

meanings.def: the position at the front of a line of people
examples: The prince rode at the head of his regiment.

meanings.def: the mass of leaves or flowers at the end of a stem
examples: Remove the dead heads to encourage new growth.

meanings.def: the mass of small bubbles on the top of a glass of beer
the part of a spot on your skin that contains a thick yellow liquid (= pus)
the component of a sound or video recording system that converts data on the disk or tape into digital electronic data (and the other way round)
used to say how many animals of a particular type are on a farm, in a herd, etc.
examples: 200 head of sheep

meanings.def: the pressure produced by steam in a small space
examples: The old engine still manages to build up a good head of steam.

meanings.def: oral sex (= using the mouth to give somebody sexual pleasure)
examples: to give head

meanings.def: the central part of a phrase, which has the same grammatical function as the whole phrase. In the phrase ‘the tall man in a suit’, man is the head.
to force people to stop arguing and behave in a sensible way
to keep trying to do something that will never be successful
examples: Trying to reason with them was like banging my head against a brick wall.

meanings.def: to be much better than other people or things
examples: His performance stood head and shoulders above the rest.

meanings.def: to shout at somebody in an angry way, especially without reason
if you bring a situation to a head or if a situation comes to a head, you are forced to deal with it quickly because it suddenly becomes very bad
examples: The chairman's resignation finally brought matters to a head.
The dispute finally came to a head in March that year.
Things came to a head when several of the nurses made a formal complaint.

meanings.def: to refuse to admit that a problem exists or refuse to deal with it
to be unable to understand something
examples: I couldn't make head nor tail of what he was saying.

meanings.def: to make somebody feel confused, upset and/or annoyed
examples: Shut up! You're doing my head in.

meanings.def: to be able to do something very easily and without having to think too much
to make somebody remember something by repeating it a lot of times
covering your whole body
examples: We were covered from head to foot in mud.
She was dressed from head to toe in red.

meanings.def: to sleep
examples: I managed to get my head down for an hour.

meanings.def: to avoid attracting attention to yourself
to be able to understand or accept something
examples: She's dead. I can't get my head round it yet.

meanings.def: to start to understand or think something
examples: When will you get it into your head that I don't want to discuss this any more!
For some reason she's got it into her head that I don't like her.

meanings.def: to allow somebody to do what they want without trying to stop them
to give somebody hopes about something that may not be possible or likely; to make somebody act or think in an unreasonable way
examples: Who's been putting ideas into his head?

meanings.def: to deal with somebody in a very direct and determined way
examples: The company will be going head to head with the giant of the pharmaceuticals market.

meanings.def: to make you feel drunk
examples: That glass of wine has gone straight to my head.

meanings.def: to make you feel too proud of yourself in a way that other people find annoying
to be aware of everything that is happening around you, even things that seem difficult or impossible to see
examples: You can’t get away with anything in her class. She has eyes in the back of her head.

meanings.def: to be a sensible person
to be good at something
examples: to have a head for figures/business

meanings.def: if somebody does not have a head for heights, they feel nervous and think they are going to fall when they look down from a high place
to be reading
examples: She always has her nose in a book.

meanings.def: to be thinking about something that is not connected with what you are doing
to have ideas, plans, etc. that are not realistic
to be a sensible person
to have somewhere to live
examples: Thanks to Bob’s generosity, I still have a roof over my head.

meanings.def: for each person
examples: The meal worked out at $20 a head.

meanings.def: moving forwards or downwards with your head in front of the rest of your body
examples: He fell head first down the stairs.

meanings.def: without thinking carefully about something before acting
examples: She got divorced and rushed head first into another marriage.

meanings.def: your head feels as though it is going round and round and you cannot balance, especially because you are ill or confused or have had a shock; to make you feel like this
examples: Her head was spinning from the pain.
His theories on economics are enough to make your head spin.

meanings.def: loving somebody very much
examples: He's fallen head over heels in love with his boss.

meanings.def: used to ask somebody which side of a coin they think will be facing upwards when it is tossed in order to decide something by chance
used to say that some people will be punished because of something that has happened
to say something that is exactly right
to force somebody to do something that they do not want to do, by making threats
to be proud of or not feel ashamed about something that you have done
examples: She managed to hold her head high and ignore what people were saying.

meanings.def: used to threaten somebody that you will hit them
involved in something that is too difficult for you to deal with
examples: After a week in the new job, I soon realized that I was in over my head.

meanings.def: to remain calm in a difficult situation
examples: She needed to keep a clear head if she was to remain in control.

meanings.def: to deal with a difficult situation, especially one in which you have financial problems, and just manage to survive
examples: I’m not sure how much longer we’ll be able to keep our heads above water.

meanings.def: to avoid attracting attention to yourself
examples: If I were you, I’d keep your head down for a couple of weeks.

meanings.def: to laugh very loudly and for a long time
to laugh, etc. a lot and very loudly
to act according to what you feel rather than to what you think is sensible
in a bad mood; in an angry way
examples: I should keep out of his way. He’s like a bear with a sore head this morning.

meanings.def: to become unable to act in a calm or sensible way
to make somebody feel annoyed, anxious or upset
examples: When they spend all this time on social media, they are seeing things that mess with their heads.

meanings.def: to be crazy
to not spend time/effort on something, because it is not important or you are not interested in it
to not hurt somebody physically in any way
just guessing or using your memory, without taking time to think carefully or check the facts
examples: I can't remember the name off the top of my head, but I can look it up for you.

meanings.def: used to describe a young person who acts in a more sensible way than you would expect for a person of their age
used to tell somebody that they will have to accept any unpleasant results of something that they decide to do
examples: Tell him the truth if you want to, but on your own head be it!

meanings.def: crazy
not knowing what you are saying or doing because of the effects of alcohol or drugs
too difficult or complicated for somebody to understand
examples: A lot of the jokes went (= were) right over my head.

meanings.def: to a higher position of authority than somebody
examples: I couldn't help feeling jealous when she was promoted over my head.
I’m not happy that you went over my head to ask for this time off.

meanings.def: an amount of money that is offered for capturing or killing somebody
examples: Ever since he killed the gang’s leader, there has been a price on his head.

meanings.def: to risk losing your job, damaging your reputation, etc. by doing or saying something
examples: It's not a matter that I'm prepared to put my head on the block for.

meanings.def: to think about or discuss something as a group
if something unpleasant rears its head or rears its ugly head, it appears or happens
to make you feel that you can still hear something
examples: His warning was still ringing in my ears.

meanings.def: to think hard in order to find an answer to something
examples: Experts have been scratching their heads over the increase in teenage crime.

meanings.def: to make people think about something in a completely different way
to be remembered for a long time
examples: One of his paintings in particular sticks in my mind.

meanings.def: to suddenly start thinking something, especially something that other people think is stupid
to suddenly decide to do something, especially something that other people think is stupid
a physical condition in which your head is painful or you cannot think clearly as a result of an illness or of drinking too much alcohol
examples: You’re going to have a thick head in the morning!

meanings.def: to make a person feel too proud in a way that other people find annoying
used to say that two people can achieve more than one person working alone
used to tell somebody to think about something, especially when they have asked for your opinion or said something stupid
examples: ‘Why don't you want to see him again?’ ‘Oh, use your head!’

idioms.def: to force people to stop arguing and behave in a sensible way

idioms.idiom: be banging, etc. your head against a brick wall
idioms.def: to keep trying to do something that will never be successful
examples: Trying to reason with them was like banging my head against a brick wall.

idioms.idiom: be/stand head and shoulders above somebody/something
idioms.def: to be much better than other people or things
examples: His performance stood head and shoulders above the rest.

idioms.def: to shout at somebody in an angry way, especially without reason

idioms.idiom: bring something to a head | come to a head
idioms.def: if you bring a situation to a head or if a situation comes to a head, you are forced to deal with it quickly because it suddenly becomes very bad
examples: The chairman's resignation finally brought matters to a head.
The dispute finally came to a head in March that year.
Things came to a head when several of the nurses made a formal complaint.

idioms.idiom: bury/hide your head in the sand
idioms.def: to refuse to admit that a problem exists or refuse to deal with it

idioms.idiom: can’t make head nor/or tail of something
idioms.def: to be unable to understand something
examples: I couldn't make head nor tail of what he was saying.

idioms.def: to make somebody feel confused, upset and/or annoyed
examples: Shut up! You're doing my head in.

idioms.idiom: do something standing on your head
idioms.def: to be able to do something very easily and without having to think too much
to make somebody remember something by repeating it a lot of times
covering your whole body
examples: We were covered from head to foot in mud.
She was dressed from head to toe in red.

idioms.def: to sleep
examples: I managed to get my head down for an hour.

idioms.def: to be able to understand or accept something
examples: She's dead. I can't get my head round it yet.

idioms.def: to start to understand or think something
examples: When will you get it into your head that I don't want to discuss this any more!
For some reason she's got it into her head that I don't like her.

idioms.def: to allow somebody to do what they want without trying to stop them

idioms.idiom: give somebody ideas | put ideas into somebody’s head
idioms.def: to give somebody hopes about something that may not be possible or likely; to make somebody act or think in an unreasonable way
examples: Who's been putting ideas into his head?

idioms.def: to deal with somebody in a very direct and determined way
examples: The company will be going head to head with the giant of the pharmaceuticals market.

idioms.def: to make you feel drunk
examples: That glass of wine has gone straight to my head.

idioms.idiom: have eyes in the back of your head
idioms.def: to be aware of everything that is happening around you, even things that seem difficult or impossible to see
examples: You can’t get away with anything in her class. She has eyes in the back of her head.

idioms.idiom: have a good head on your shoulders
idioms.def: to be a sensible person
to be good at something
examples: to have a head for figures/business

idioms.idiom: have your head/nose in a book
idioms.def: to be reading
examples: She always has her nose in a book.

idioms.idiom: have your head in the clouds
idioms.def: to be thinking about something that is not connected with what you are doing

idioms.idiom: have your head screwed on (the right way)
idioms.def: to be a sensible person

idioms.idiom: have a roof over your head
idioms.def: to have somewhere to live
examples: Thanks to Bob’s generosity, I still have a roof over my head.

idioms.def: for each person
examples: The meal worked out at $20 a head.

idioms.def: moving forwards or downwards with your head in front of the rest of your body
examples: He fell head first down the stairs.
She got divorced and rushed head first into another marriage.

idioms.idiom: your head is spinning | make your head spin
idioms.def: your head feels as though it is going round and round and you cannot balance, especially because you are ill or confused or have had a shock; to make you feel like this
examples: Her head was spinning from the pain.
His theories on economics are enough to make your head spin.

idioms.def: loving somebody very much
examples: He's fallen head over heels in love with his boss.

idioms.def: used to ask somebody which side of a coin they think will be facing upwards when it is tossed in order to decide something by chance
used to say that some people will be punished because of something that has happened

idioms.idiom: hit the nail on the head
idioms.def: to say something that is exactly right

idioms.idiom: hold/put a gun to somebody’s head
idioms.def: to force somebody to do something that they do not want to do, by making threats

idioms.idiom: hold your head high | hold up your head
idioms.def: to be proud of or not feel ashamed about something that you have done
examples: She managed to hold her head high and ignore what people were saying.

idioms.def: used to threaten somebody that you will hit them
involved in something that is too difficult for you to deal with
examples: After a week in the new job, I soon realized that I was in over my head.

idioms.idiom: keep your head | keep a clear/cool head
idioms.def: to remain calm in a difficult situation
examples: She needed to keep a clear head if she was to remain in control.

idioms.def: to deal with a difficult situation, especially one in which you have financial problems, and just manage to survive
examples: I’m not sure how much longer we’ll be able to keep our heads above water.

idioms.def: to avoid attracting attention to yourself
examples: If I were you, I’d keep your head down for a couple of weeks.

idioms.def: to laugh very loudly and for a long time

idioms.idiom: laugh, scream, etc. your head off
idioms.def: to laugh, etc. a lot and very loudly

idioms.idiom: let your heart rule your head
idioms.def: to act according to what you feel rather than to what you think is sensible

idioms.idiom: like a bear with a sore head
idioms.def: in a bad mood; in an angry way
examples: I should keep out of his way. He’s like a bear with a sore head this morning.

idioms.def: to become unable to act in a calm or sensible way
to make somebody feel annoyed, anxious or upset
examples: When they spend all this time on social media, they are seeing things that mess with their heads.

idioms.def: to be crazy

idioms.idiom: not bother yourself/your head with/about something
idioms.def: to not spend time/effort on something, because it is not important or you are not interested in it

idioms.idiom: not harm/touch a hair of somebody’s head
idioms.def: to not hurt somebody physically in any way

idioms.idiom: off the top of your head
idioms.def: just guessing or using your memory, without taking time to think carefully or check the facts
examples: I can't remember the name off the top of my head, but I can look it up for you.

idioms.idiom: (have) an old head on young shoulders
idioms.def: used to describe a young person who acts in a more sensible way than you would expect for a person of their age
used to tell somebody that they will have to accept any unpleasant results of something that they decide to do
examples: Tell him the truth if you want to, but on your own head be it!

idioms.def: crazy
too difficult or complicated for somebody to understand
examples: A lot of the jokes went (= were) right over my head.
I couldn't help feeling jealous when she was promoted over my head.
I’m not happy that you went over my head to ask for this time off.

idioms.def: an amount of money that is offered for capturing or killing somebody
examples: Ever since he killed the gang’s leader, there has been a price on his head.

idioms.idiom: put/lay your head/neck on the block
idioms.def: to risk losing your job, damaging your reputation, etc. by doing or saying something
examples: It's not a matter that I'm prepared to put my head on the block for.

idioms.def: to think about or discuss something as a group
if something unpleasant rears its head or rears its ugly head, it appears or happens
to make you feel that you can still hear something
examples: His warning was still ringing in my ears.

idioms.def: to think hard in order to find an answer to something
examples: Experts have been scratching their heads over the increase in teenage crime.

idioms.def: to make people think about something in a completely different way
to be remembered for a long time
examples: One of his paintings in particular sticks in my mind.

idioms.idiom: take it into your head that…
idioms.def: to suddenly start thinking something, especially something that other people think is stupid

idioms.idiom: take it into your head to do something
idioms.def: to suddenly decide to do something, especially something that other people think is stupid
a physical condition in which your head is painful or you cannot think clearly as a result of an illness or of drinking too much alcohol
examples: You’re going to have a thick head in the morning!

idioms.def: to make a person feel too proud in a way that other people find annoying

idioms.idiom: two heads are better than one
idioms.def: used to say that two people can achieve more than one person working alone
used to tell somebody to think about something, especially when they have asked for your opinion or said something stupid
examples: ‘Why don't you want to see him again?’ ‘Oh, use your head!’

meanings.def: (in nouns) a person who is very enthusiastic about a particular thing or is addicted to a particular drug
examples: a gearhead
a crackhead
a smackhead
a pothead

meanings.def: to move in a particular direction
examples: Where are we heading?
Where are you two headed?
Let's head back home.
They woke early and headed off for breakfast.
She headed for the door.
We headed north.
Head towards the mall.
The boat was heading out to sea.
(figurative) Can you forecast where the economy is heading?
She stood up and headed toward the exit.
We headed straight back to school.
We headed west for two days.

meanings.def: to lead or be in charge of something
examples: She has been appointed to head the research team.
to head a committee/delegation
to head an investigation/inquiry
a terrorist group headed by a former army officer
He heads up the bank's corporate arm.
The committee will be headed jointly by two men.
The delegation will be headed by Lord Arthur.
Eight out of ten children came from a family headed by both natural parents.
He ended up heading a minority government.

meanings.def: to be at the top of a list of names or at the front of a line of people
examples: Italy heads the table after two games.
Orlando, Florida, heads the list of most popular summer destinations.
to head a march/procession

meanings.def: to put a word or words at the top of a page or section of a book as a title
examples: be headed… The chapter was headed ‘My Early Life’.

meanings.def: to hit a football with your head
examples: Walsh headed the ball into an empty goal.
